s.text: Chromosome-size DNA was prepared from yeast transformants carrying circular YACs, separated by clamped homogeneous electrical field gel electrophoresis (CHEF), transferred onto a nylon membrane, and hybridized with an alphoid DNA probe or Alu -probe (see above).
Moreover, the new system provides an alternative approach to selectively clone large fragments of bacterial genomes [ 18 ] that are poor in sequences that can function as ARS s in yeast [ 14 ] .
As expected, the number of transformants was roughly one order of magnitude higher than that obtained with counter-selection (Table 4).

Because TAR cloning produces multiple gene isolates, it allows the isolation of both parental alleles of the gene which can then be used for haplotype analysis [ 24 ] . Recently we found that up to 15% DNA divergence does not preclude efficient gene isolation by TAR [ 25 ] . Such tolerance to DNA divergence allows the isolation of highly polymorphic alleles and gene and homologues with the same TAR vector.

To study in greater detail how the presence of nonhomologous DNA at the end of one of the hooks reduces gene capture efficiency, we constructed a set of TAR vectors with different lengths of nonhomologous DNA next to the hook.
Each vector contained a 60-bp transgene-specific hook and a common B1 repeat as the second hook.

This configuration allowed us to linearize the vector by a different combination of enzymes, producing a set of TAR constructs with different lengths of nonhomologous DNA at the end of the specific hook (Fig.

In our construct, we deleted this adaptor to prevent use of the start codon for translation; that would result in nonexpression of the functional URA3 gene and, therefore, an inability to grow in the absence of uracil.
